body:
Hah, I just wanted to create same issue today because I stumbled upon this in my app.
So, I will enhance this issue with info and proposal, and, if maintainers agree on my vision, 
**I am happy and ready to tackle on implementing the code, docs, test and release notes.** ðŸ™‚

## Proposal

I want to add an `Initialize` schedule that *actually* runs the first no matter what.

## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

In my game, I have a `Tree` component (the usual, wooden one). In order to keep separation of concerns, I only specify general required components via attributes on `Tree` itself, and split other by registering them via `world.register_required_components_with` in submodules. I hade previously done it in `PreStartup` schedule, but it works only if the game starts not in the `State` that somehow touches `Tree`s, or else I get `called Result::unwrap() on an Err value: ArchetypeExists(ComponentId(...))`.

As a side note - maybe this error should be improved somehow? Is this possible? Can tackle this too.

## What solution would you like?

Something in the lines of:

```rust
#[derive(ScheduleLabel, Clone, Debug, PartialEq, Eq, Hash)]
pub struct Initialize;

...

let mut main_schedule_order = app.world_mut().resource_mut::<MainScheduleOrder>();
main_schedule_order.insert_startup_before(StateTransition, Initialize);
```

Edit: this is how I do it in my app, for bevy it should be probably inserted in `bevy_ecs` as the first, while `bevy_state` will insert `StateTransition` after `Initialize`, not before `PreStartup`.

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

1. Leaving as is, I think it is not great because it can be misleading.
2. Making `Initialize` being *always* the first, no matter what user code does with schedules by making it a specific case in ECS internals. I think this will not add much value, and deny users in making some very special stuff that must run *before* `Initialize` (I haven't come up with a use case for that, but unnecessary limitations are not good in general I think).

Waiting for blessing, I think I need your opinion @alice-i-cecile.
I consider this to be misbehavior on the part of `bevy_state` personally. As far as `bevy_ecs` is aware, `PreStartup` _is_ the first schedule, but `bevy_state` inserts its own schedule before that.

@benfrankel On the one hand, I agree with you, but on the other - `StateTransition` manages state of, well, `State`, so if your system relies on the correct `State` it can be useful to have some `bevy`-native schedule that is run before `Startup`, but after `StateTransition`.

Edit: I think most game logic should run in the current place of `PreStartup`, while proposed `Initialize` should be used for stuff that relies on running before *any* logic ran at all (registering required components, hooks, etc.)

Initial state transitions could occur as normal in the `StateTransition` schedule before `Update` if `bevy_state` supported state disabling so that not being in _any_ of the states of state type `A` (which most notably is the case during startup) is treated as a valid program state.

Interesting point - I have neither a strong nor a justified opinion on whether the startup phase should happen in a not-yet-in-any-state state.
My gut feeling is somewhat against, but that is not valuable.

If it is considered the way bevy state should function - then your proposed solution of moving `StateTransition` to *after* `Startup` is the best way, and I will be happy to implement it! ðŸ™‚ 

If not - making an `Initialize` schedule can fix the inconsistency.

Seems that this issue is happened to be *a bit* controversial haha
Actually `StateTransition` runs in two places currently: before `PreStartup` _and_ before `Update` :)
I assume that this was made specifically so that an app is always in some `State` and never in not-yet-in-any-state state. So the choice I wrote about above should influence this too ðŸ™‚

As discussed in https://discord.com/channels/691052431525675048/749335865876021248/1354607912260997361 with @alice-i-cecile, I will make a doc PR documenting current behaviour, and make a new issue summarizing the discussion here, as it can be controversial and we should not postpone the docs because of it.

issue.title: Fix misleading documentation of Main schedule

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Fixes #18562.

## Solution

- Specified that `StateTransition` is actually run before `PreStartup`.
- Specified consequences of this and how to actually run systems before any game logic regardless of state.
- Updated docs of `StateTransition` to reflect that it is run before `PreStartup` in addition to being run after `PreUpdate`.

## Testing

- `cargo doc`
- `cargo test --doc`

issue.title: Use hooks + immutable components pattern for state transitions

labels.name: C-Feature
labels.description: A new feature, making something new possible

labels.name: S-Blocked
labels.description: This cannot move forward until something else changes

labels.name: X-Controversial
labels.description: There is active debate or serious implications around merging this PR

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

The current schedule-based approach to state transitions is messy.
It allows for system ordering ambiguities (#13947), and forces users to reason about a once-per-frame `StateTransition` schedule (which other crates may add more copies of).

State transitions hold important global invariants: we should use our new tools to make it easier (and more consistent) to reason about them.

## What solution would you like?

1. Remove the `StateTransition` schedule.
2. Make `State<T>` immutable (blocked on #17485).
3. Remove `NextState`, and make users change states via commands.
4. Use hooks to call the `OnEnter`/`OnExit`/`OnTransition` schedules when the state changes.
5. Remove `.init_state` in favor of simply calling `.init_resource` on states. (Use a deprecation notice to make this easier).

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

#18562 discusses the possibility of adding another schedule before the initial state transition to allow for startup systems to run before states are entered.

I feel strongly that we shouldn't do this: it should be impossible to be in a state without its on-enter systems to be called (and similarly for on-exit). Instead, we should enforce this invariant as strongly as possible, and ensure that users have the tools needed to delay entering into states until any requisite setup is complete.

## Additional context

Note that this conflicts with the desire to run something *before* states are entered stated in #18562. However, users could simply initialize their starting states in a system during `Startup`, rather than calling `.init_state`.
